article.title: Afterglows and Kilonovae Associated with Nearby Low-Luminosity Short-Duration Gamma-Ray Bursts: Application to GW170817/GRB170817A

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 1(a), what happens to the peak of the X-ray light curves as the viewing angle increases?
choices: The peak luminosity increases and the peak time delays.
The peak luminosity stays the same, but the peak time delays.
The peak luminosity decays and the peak time shifts to earlier times.
The peak luminosity decays and the peak time delays.

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 1(b), what do the dashed and dotted lines represent?
choices: Afterglow emission for different viewing angles.
Kilonova emission for different ejecta masses and velocities.
Radio emission for different viewing angles.
Spectrum evolution for different viewing angles.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main takeaway from Figure 1(c) regarding radio light curves?
choices: Radio light curves are not affected by viewing angle.
Radio light curves peak earlier for larger viewing angles.
Radio light curves peak later for larger viewing angles.
Radio emission is always dominant over kilonova emission.

multiple_choice_question.text: What information does Figure 1(d) provide about the synchrotron emission in this scenario?
choices: It remains in the fast cooling regime throughout the observation.
It transitions from the fast cooling regime to the slow cooling regime.
It remains in the slow cooling regime throughout the observation.
It transitions from the slow cooling regime to the fast cooling regime.

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 3(a), how does the flux level of the X-ray light curves change with decreasing medium density (n)?
choices: The flux level increases.
The flux level remains the same.
The flux level drops.
The flux level fluctuates.

multiple_choice_question.text: What causes the variation in the radio light curve shape with different medium densities in Figure 3(c)?
choices: Variation in kilonova emission.
Change in viewing angle.
Crossing between the self-absorption frequency and the radio frequency for higher densities.
Interaction of the ejecta with the surrounding medium.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main difference between Figure 3 and Figure 1, which shows a structured jet model?
choices: The overall flux levels are significantly higher in Figure 3.
Figure 3 shows a much slower rise and later peak time for afterglow emission.
The kilonova signal is significantly brighter in Figure 3.
The spectrum evolution shows a transition from slow to fast cooling regime in Figure 3.

multiple_choice_question.text: What information does the parameter corner plot in Figure 6 primarily provide?
choices: Constraints on the viewing angle of the GRB jet.
Best-fitting values for ejecta mass (Mej) and velocity (vej) of the kilonova.
Estimation of the GRB jet energy and Lorentz factor.
The density of the surrounding interstellar medium.
